title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 21 september [1865]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 21 September [1865]
text: 1865September 21Dear Walti have just received your letter all right with the 10 dlrdollars for hanna which i will give her to get what she likes she is very gratefullgrateful for the present you say if i want money at any time to send to you you must not deny yourself any comforts only send what you you can very conveintlyconveniently spare the fare was much more than i expected it was 12 dollars it used to be 7 i begin to feel a little as if i wanted to go back but han wontwon't hear a word about it i have had a letter from Jeffy and one from Matty but none from george i suppose he is very busy Jeff says he has got a job to new york rather a big job i should think Jeffy says he is not going to doodo any thing in the way of building his house this winter i was very sorry to hear that as i was in hopes he would have a place of his own he says brick is so very high i dontdon't know but what we shall all have to go to birminghamBurlington to live every thing is so monstrous dear i have heard more about the place to day it certainly is quite a desirable place people that has lived here at burlingtonBurlington would not come here to live but likes it there much better there is many well off farmers and provitions is low so a person could live if they had a small income i want to go and see it but Mr Heyd isentisn't favorable to it) Walt doodo you feel well or are you overtaxed in your work that the warm weather affected you sooso i wish Walter you would write to the doctor at flatbussFlatbushand see how Jessee is and let me know i cant help but think so much about him i suppossuppose its because i am here and dontdon't have the children to take my time) every thing seems to go on here lately very well the living is very good and all i dontdon't know as i feel any better than i did at home i feel pretty well i get a little home sick once in a while i told han to daytoday i must go back in two weeks she made a great time she said you said i must stay 3 months i am very sorry Jeffy sent the wrong papers if you wish them you had better write to Jeffy to send them i have not been out any since i have been here i have been waiting for han to go with me i want to get some flannel and stocking and a few other things han says she will write to you soon give my love to the people of your house and the old lady in particular i would not write with a pencil if i had pen and ink but i must write with somethingyour motherL Whit Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 21 September [1865]
